okily dokily. I poked through the big paper, and it said what you just
said, but I'm still stuck on the competing conventions problem. Your
paper didn't present any opposing views to compare historical markers
to. I'm still pretty new to the field, and I don't understand what kinds
of alternatives exist. Is this a totally new approach, or is there some
computationally intensive way of compareing traits/genes that might also
be studied? I seems to me that two species that evolve totally
independantly until their history seperates them to much, and they will
not be afforded significant chance to combine. ( less than 1% as you say
)
If there were a function to evaluate the compatability of two networks (
perhapse that were representative of a species ) than the likelyhood of
succesfull interspecies crossovers would increase.
so has this tree been barked up by plenty of other dogs, or is there
something to play with here?
chad 

------=_NextPart_000_49D1_01C4831B.6AE7FA80

<HTML>
<BODY>
okily dokily. I poked through the big paper, and it said what you just said, but I'm still stuck on the competing conventions problem. Your paper didn't present any opposing views to compare historical markers to. I'm still pretty new to the field, and I don't understand what kinds of alternatives exist. Is this a totally new approach, or is there some computationally intensive way of compareing traits/genes that might also be studied? I seems to me that two species that evolve totally independantly until their history seperates them to much, and they will not be afforded significant chance to combine. ( less than 1% as you say )<br>
If there were a function to evaluate the compatability of two networks ( perhapse that were representative of a species ) than the likelyhood of succesfull interspecies crossovers would increase.<br>
so has this tree been barked up by plenty of other dogs, or is there something to play with here?<br>
chad
</BODY></HTML>
